answers.title: Is there something like Annotation Inheritance in java?
answers.body:
In addition to Grygoriys answer of annotating annotations.

You can check e.g. methods for containing a @Qualifier annotation (or an annotation annotated with @Qualifier) by this loop:

for (Annotation a : method.getAnnotations()) {
    if (a.annotationType().isAnnotationPresent(Qualifier.class)) {
        System.out.println("found @Qualifier annotation");//found annotation having Qualifier annotation itself
    }
}

What you're basically doing, is to get all annotations present on the method and of those annotations you get their types and check those types if they're annotated with @Qualifier. Your annotation needs to be Target.Annotation_type enabled as well to get this working.

answers.title: Is there something like Annotation Inheritance in java?
answers.body:
Check out https://github.com/blindpirate/annotation-magic , which is a library I developed when I had the same question.

@interface Animal {
    boolean fluffy() default false;

    String name() default "";
}

@Extends(Animal.class)
@Animal(fluffy = true)
@interface Pet {
    String name();
}

@Extends(Pet.class)
@interface Cat {
    @AliasFor("name")
    String value();
}

@Extends(Pet.class)
@interface Dog {
    String name();
}

@interface Rat {
    @AliasFor(target = Animal.class, value = "name")
    String value();
}

@Cat("Tom")
class MyClass {
    @Dog(name = "Spike")
    @Rat("Jerry")
    public void foo() {
    }
}

        Pet petAnnotation = AnnotationMagic.getOneAnnotationOnClassOrNull(MyClass.class, Pet.class);
        assertEquals("Tom", petAnnotation.name());
        assertTrue(AnnotationMagic.instanceOf(petAnnotation, Animal.class));

        Animal animalAnnotation = AnnotationMagic.getOneAnnotationOnClassOrNull(MyClass.class, Animal.class);
        assertTrue(animalAnnotation.fluffy());

        Method fooMethod = MyClass.class.getMethod("foo");
        List<Animal> animalAnnotations = AnnotationMagic.getAnnotationsOnMethod(fooMethod, Animal.class);
        assertEquals(Arrays.asList("Spike", "Jerry"), animalAnnotations.stream().map(Animal::name).collect(toList()));

answers.title: io.github.jan.supabase.exceptions.BadRequestRestException: Error (headers must have required property 'authorization') from supabase-kt
answers.body:
Apparently the supabase-kt library will use the API key as authentication and add the Authorization=Bearer ... header to the API request only if the GoTrue plugin is installed.

Adding the GoTrue plugin resolved this error.

I added the GoTrue plugin by adding the following lines to my module level build.gradle file:

implementation platform('io.github.jan-tennert.supabase:bom:1.0.0')
implementation 'io.github.jan-tennert.supabase:gotrue-kt:1.0.0'

And then by adding it to createSupabaseClient() like so:

val client = createSupabaseClient(
    supabaseUrl = BuildConfig.supabase_project_url,
    supabaseKey = BuildConfig.supabase_project_api_key,
) {
    install(Storage) {

    }
    install(GoTrue) {

    }
}

Side note: after making the above changes I still got a Invalid JWT - new row violates row-level security policy for table "objects" error, but I was able to fix that by adding a new policy on the Supabase dashboard(SQL expression for it: (bucket_id = 'insert-bucket-name'::text))

answers.title: How to find an index of the ArrayList from the starting index in Java?
answers.body:
Your code finds the index within the sublist.

To find the index within the original list, add the index used to create the sublist to the result:

System.out.println(bricks.subList(1, bricks.size()).indexOf("CCCC") + 1);

Some refactoring makes this clearer:

public static <T> int indexOfAfter(List<T> list, T item, int from) {
    int result = list.subList(from, list.size()).indexOf(item);
    return result == -1 ? -1 : (from + result);
}

answers.title: How to find an index of the ArrayList from the starting index in Java?
answers.body:
import java.util.*;

public class Test{
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int startIndex = 1;
        ArrayList<String> bricks = new ArrayList<String>(List.of("BBBB","CCCC","DDDD"));
        int index = bricks.subList(startIndex, bricks.size()).indexOf("CCCC");
        if(index != -1){
            index = index + startIndex;
        }
        System.out.println(index);
    }
}

answers.title: How to find an index of the ArrayList from the starting index in Java?
answers.body:
You could write your own helper:

static <T> int indexOf(List<T> list, int offset, T element) {
    for (int i = offset; i < list.size(); i++) {
        if (Objects.equals(list.get(i), element)) {
            return i;
        }
    }
    return -1;
}

Note that this may be inefficient for non-random-access lists like LinkedList. It also handles the lower bound differently from the upper bound, but that can be fixed with an additional check.

answers.body_markdown:
See [DateTimeFormatter][1]. It should be `HH` for 24 hours time (0-23) i.o. `hh` for 12 hours time (1-12). The error is caused by hour "00". Fortunately, otherwise you would have only the first half of the day.

See h, k, H and K. 

The class `Instant` does not use units like seconds, is more a long internally. Use `LocalDateTime` for your format.

  [1]: https://In%20every%20case%20it%20should%20be%20%60HH%60%20for%2024%20hours%20time%20i.o.%20%60hh%60%20for%2012%20hours%20time.
answers.title: Parsing Instant using OpenCsv
answers.body:
See DateTimeFormatter. It should be HH for 24 hours time (0-23) i.o. hh for 12 hours time (1-12). The error is caused by hour "00". Fortunately, otherwise you would have only the first half of the day.

See h, k, H and K.

The class Instant does not use units like seconds, is more a long internally. Use LocalDateTime for your format.

answers.title: Parsing Instant using OpenCsv
answers.body:
What comes from my investigation, is that the root cause is the lack of a time zone, but my question is how do I specify the time zone using the annotation only?

I haven't find a way to change the timezone of the DateTimeFormatter used by OpenCSV. You could, in theory, use @CsvCustomBindByName and provide a custom converter in which you can use your own DateTimeFormatter with the timezone you want.

However, if you also control how your CSV is generated, you can simply use the following datetime patterns to make it work with Instant:

@CsvBindByName(column = "date")
@CsvDate(
        value = "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ssX",
        writeFormat = "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss'Z'",
        writeFormatEqualsReadFormat = false)
private Instant date;

value is the pattern used when reading a bean from a CSV file. X is a pattern letter which will corresponds to the zone offset, i.e. when reading the 'Z' character, it will assume the time to be in UTC+00:00. See doc.

When writing a bean to a CSV file, the writeFormat pattern will be used and needs to be different, you need to print the 'Z' char manually at the end, hence the escaped 'Z'. The reason is that internally OpenCSV does the following when writing an Instant:

LocalDateTime ldt = LocalDateTime.ofInstant((Instant) value, ZoneId.of("UTC"));
return writeDtf.format(ldt);

LocalDateTime does not have a timezone, so the X cannot be used. Arguably, they could instead do the following:

return writeDtf.withZone(ZoneOffset.UTC).format(value);

Which would then allow us to use the X. They could also do the same when parsing a date to an Instant, in order to be consistent.

answers.body_markdown:
You should probably read [this documentation][1]. It's specifically a setting for users in the EEA (European Economic Area) that helps with GDPR compliance - it sets a certain tag in your requests, which limits specific types of data usage by the ad requests and the ad vendors. There's a similar one in the section above (`setTagForChildDirectedTreatment`) which relates to California law. (They're not *true* or *false* booleans either, they're int constants - check the documentation!)

Basically, the idea is that if you're going to be displaying ads in your app, and providing data to app vendors, there are laws that you need to comply with depending on where the user is located - in this case related to the user's age. These settings allow you to configure ad requests in a way that *should** comply with those laws.

So it's up to you to do things like working out where the user is located (so you can comply with the legislation that covers them), and whether they're underage. Usually you do that by showing a splash screen that requires some kind of confirmation - a typical one is asking for their date of birth (you've probably run into that yourself!) so you can calculate their age and act accordingly.

The important thing is to confirm this before you send an ad request - don't assume they're an adult either, it's probably better to fall back to the safest configuration and only update it to *"above the age of consent"*, *"personalised ads allowed"* etc when you get confirmation. That way you're not breaking any laws before you realise you're not allowed to do that.

----

So you're relying on the user to tell the truth here, which is why you should make it a splash screen, something they can't dismiss - they have to make a declaration one way or the other. That's all you can really do.

But let me stress here, **this is only my interpretation of it**, and **this is definitely not legal advice**. You'll notice the language around all this stuff is about *helping you to comply* etc - there are no legal guarantees, and ultimately it's your responsibility to adhere to the appropriate legislation. Unfortunately that can lead to advice and *best practices* being a little vague or non-committal - it's rare to get any official *"do this and this and you're golden"* documentation, and you can end up with some stuff feeling unanswered. If you feel that way, it's not just you!


  [1]: https://developers.google.com/admob/android/targeting#users_under_the_age_of_consent
answers.title: What is setTagForUnderAgeOfConsent(boolean) used for in UMP sdk?
answers.body:
You should probably read this documentation. It's specifically a setting for users in the EEA (European Economic Area) that helps with GDPR compliance - it sets a certain tag in your requests, which limits specific types of data usage by the ad requests and the ad vendors. There's a similar one in the section above (setTagForChildDirectedTreatment) which relates to California law. (They're not true or false booleans either, they're int constants - check the documentation!)

Basically, the idea is that if you're going to be displaying ads in your app, and providing data to app vendors, there are laws that you need to comply with depending on where the user is located - in this case related to the user's age. These settings allow you to configure ad requests in a way that should* comply with those laws.

So it's up to you to do things like working out where the user is located (so you can comply with the legislation that covers them), and whether they're underage. Usually you do that by showing a splash screen that requires some kind of confirmation - a typical one is asking for their date of birth (you've probably run into that yourself!) so you can calculate their age and act accordingly.

The important thing is to confirm this before you send an ad request - don't assume they're an adult either, it's probably better to fall back to the safest configuration and only update it to "above the age of consent", "personalised ads allowed" etc when you get confirmation. That way you're not breaking any laws before you realise you're not allowed to do that.

So you're relying on the user to tell the truth here, which is why you should make it a splash screen, something they can't dismiss - they have to make a declaration one way or the other. That's all you can really do.

But let me stress here, this is only my interpretation of it, and this is definitely not legal advice. You'll notice the language around all this stuff is about helping you to comply etc - there are no legal guarantees, and ultimately it's your responsibility to adhere to the appropriate legislation. Unfortunately that can lead to advice and best practices being a little vague or non-committal - it's rare to get any official "do this and this and you're golden" documentation, and you can end up with some stuff feeling unanswered. If you feel that way, it's not just you!

comments.body_markdown: `while (!end) {` and ... no - most defiantly not within a context of Swing app. Swing is not thread safe and is single threaded.  You've actually lucked out not locking your app up. Take some time to have a look at [Concurrency in Swing](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/uiswing/concurrency/index.html) and consider using a [Swing `Timer`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/uiswing/misc/timer.html) for the main game loop and a [`SwingWorker`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/uiswing/concurrency/worker.html) to handle the comms

items.title: Java server stops receiving updates and throws "IOException: server null error"
items.body:
I'm working on a Java LAN multiplayer application where the two players control ant colonies that fight each other. The script is set up in a way where both players possess a list of player one's ants and player two's ants. For every tick player one and player two exchange their respective lists.

This setup runs smoothly and accepts connections, but once two ants from opposite sides collide the two games unsync and throw "IOException: server null error". this causes both sides to stop receiving any updates from the other side.

I suspect this has something to do with safe thread structure but I have yet to find a way to solve this problem.

Here is my code (imports left out)

Main.java

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
      System.out.print("Are you above a server (true/false)?");  
      Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);      
      boolean isServer = sc.nextBoolean();
      Frame frame = new Frame(isServer);
      frame.setSize(900, 500);
  }

}

ServerTest.java

public class ServerTest{
  private ArrayList<Ant> p1Ants;
  private ArrayList<Ant> p2Ants;
  
  private ServerSocket serverSocket;

  private Frame MyFrame;
  
  public ServerTest(){
    //server will send p1 ants and receive p2 ants
    try{
      serverSocket = new ServerSocket(6355);
    }
    catch (IOException e) {
      System.out.println("IOExpection server startup " + e.getMessage());
    }
  }

  public void send(ArrayList<Ant> list){
    try {
        System.out.println("sending");
        // Convert ArrayList to byte array
        ByteArrayOutputStream byteArrayOutputStream = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
        ObjectOutputStream objectOutputStream = new ObjectOutputStream(byteArrayOutputStream);
        objectOutputStream.writeObject(list);
        objectOutputStream.flush();
        byte[] byteArray = byteArrayOutputStream.toByteArray();
        
        // Send byte array over the socket
        Socket socket = new Socket("localhost", 6455);
        System.out.println(socket.getRemoteSocketAddress().toString());
        OutputStream outputStream = socket.getOutputStream();
        outputStream.write(byteArray);
        outputStream.flush();
        System.out.println("ArrayList sent successfully.");
        
        socket.close();
    } 
    catch (IOException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
    
  }

  public ArrayList<Ant> receive(){
    try {
      System.out.println("Waiting for connection...");

      Socket clientSocket = serverSocket.accept();
      System.out.println("Connection established.");

      InputStream inputStream = clientSocket.getInputStream();
      byte[] receivedData = new byte[1024];
      int bytesRead = inputStream.read(receivedData);

      ByteArrayInputStream byteArrayInputStream = new ByteArrayInputStream(receivedData);
      ObjectInputStream objectInputStream = new ObjectInputStream(byteArrayInputStream);
      ArrayList<Ant> receivedArrayList = (ArrayList<Ant>) objectInputStream.readObject();
      
      p2Ants = receivedArrayList;
      
      return p2Ants;

    } 
    catch(ClassNotFoundException e){
      System.out.println("ClassNotFoundExpection");
      return null;
    }
    catch (IOException e) {
      System.out.println("IOExpection server "+ e.getMessage());
      return null;
    }
    
  }
  
}

ClientTest.java (Same as ServerTest but swapped ports)

public class ClientTest{
  private ArrayList<Ant> p1Ants;
  private ArrayList<Ant> p2Ants;
  
  private ServerSocket serverSocket;
  
  public ClientTest(){
    //Client will send p2 ants and receive p1 ants
    try{
      serverSocket = new ServerSocket(6455);
    }

    }
  }

Frame.java

public class Frame extends JPanel {

  private int HEIGHT = 500;
  private int WIDTH = 900;
  private JFrame APP;
  private boolean end = false;

  //server & client stuff
  private boolean isServer;
  private ServerTest server;
  private ClientTest client;

  // PLAYER1
  private ArrayList<Ant> p1Ants = new ArrayList<Ant>();
  private AntMound p1Mound;

  // PLAYER2
  private ArrayList<Ant> p2Ants = new ArrayList<Ant>();
  private AntMound p2Mound;
  
  //GUI
  private JButton upgradeCashPerSecond;
  private JButton upgradeCashPerKill;
  private JButton spawnRate;
  //GUI

  public Frame(boolean isSer) {
      
    setLayout(new FlowLayout()); 
      
    //server & client stuff
    isServer = isSer;
    if(isServer){
      server = new ServerTest();
    }
    else{
      client = new ClientTest();
    }
    
    // temp stuff
    p1Mound = new AntMound(100, 10.0, "p1", new FireAnt("p1"));
    p2Mound = new AntMound(100, 20.0, "p2", new BulletAnt("p2"));
    // temp stuff

    // Show frame
    APP = new JFrame("Hive Havoc");
    APP.pack();
    APP.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
    APP.getContentPane().add(this);
    APP.setVisible(true);
    APP.setSize(WIDTH, HEIGHT);
    
    

    // GAME LOOP
    while (!end) {
      APP.repaint();
      sleep(100);
      //if client get p1 ants if server get p2 ants
      if(isServer){
         ArrayList<Ant> temp = p2Ants;
         p2Ants = server.receive();
         if(p2Ants == null)
            p2Ants = temp;
         server.send(p1Ants);
         
      }
      else{
         client.send(p2Ants);
         ArrayList<Ant> temp = p1Ants;
         p1Ants = client.receive();
         if(p1Ants == null)
            p1Ants = temp;
      }
      
    }

  }

  @Override
  protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
    super.paintComponent(g);
    System.out.println("Drawing and we are: " + isServer);
    
    
    if (p1Mound != null) {
      // draw p1 ants
      for (int i = 0; i < p1Ants.size(); i++) {
        Ant ant = p1Ants.get(i);
        ant.setImg();
        if(isServer){
          if (ant.getHealth() <= 0) {
            p1Ants.remove(i);
            p2Mound.getCash(10);
          } else if (p2Mound != null) {
            ant.moveAnt(p2Ants, p2Mound);
          }
        }
        ant.draw(g);
      }
    }
    if (p2Mound != null) {
      // draw p2 ants
      for (int i = 0; i < p2Ants.size(); i++) {
        Ant ant = p2Ants.get(i);
        ant.setImg();
        if(!isServer){
          if (ant.getHealth() <= 0) {
            p2Ants.remove(i);
            p1Mound.getCash(10);
          } else if (p1Mound != null) {
            ant.moveAnt(p1Ants, p1Mound);
          }
        }
        ant.draw(g);
      }
    }

    // spawn ants
    if (p1Mound != null && p1Mound.readyToSpawn() && isServer) {
      p1Ants.add(new Ant(p1Mound.getAnt().getHealth(), p1Mound.getAnt().getSpeed(), p1Mound.getAnt().getDamage(),
          p1Mound.getAnt().getName(), "p1"));
    }
    if (p2Mound != null && p2Mound.readyToSpawn() && !isServer) {
      p2Ants.add(new Ant(p2Mound.getAnt().getHealth(), p2Mound.getAnt().getSpeed(), p2Mound.getAnt().getDamage(),
          p2Mound.getAnt().getName(), "p2"));
    }

    // kil mounds
    if (p1Mound != null && p1Mound.getHealth() <= 0) {
      p1Mound = null;
      System.out.println("p1 dead");
      end = true;
    }
    if (p2Mound != null && p2Mound.getHealth() <= 0) {
      p2Mound = null;
      System.out.println("p2 dead");
      end = true;
    }

    // Draw mounds
    if (p1Mound != null) {
      p1Mound.draw(g);
    }
    if (p2Mound != null) {
      p2Mound.draw(g);
    }

  }

  public int getH() {
    return HEIGHT;
  }

  public int getW() {
    return WIDTH;
  }

  public ArrayList<Ant> getP1Ants() {
    return p1Ants;
  }

  public ArrayList<Ant> getP2Ants() {
    return p2Ants;
  }

  public void sleep(int T) {
    try {
      Thread.sleep(T);
    } catch (InterruptedException e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    }
  }

}

Ant.java

public class Ant implements Serializable {
  private double health;
  private double speed;
  private double damage;
  private String name;
  private String player;
  private int ani_step = 0;
  private boolean ani_dir = true;
  private int x = 0;
  private int y = 0;
  private int rX = 0;
  private int rY = 0;
  private boolean atTarget = true;

  private int HEIGHT = 500;
  private int WIDTH = 900;
  
  private transient BufferedImage spriteSheet;

  private int size_cut = 4;

  public Ant(double h, double s, double d, String n, String play) {
    health = h;
    speed = s;
    damage = d;
    name = n;
    player = play;

    if(player.equals("p1")){

      x = 50;
      y = HEIGHT/2;
    }
    else{
      //set p2 spawn
      x = 850;
      y = HEIGHT/2;
    }

    try {
      spriteSheet = null;
    } catch (Exception v) {
      spriteSheet = null;
    }
  }

   try {

  public void moveAnt(ArrayList<Ant> ants, AntMound antHill) {
    int antHillX = antHill.getX();
    int antHillY = antHill.getY();
    //System.out.println("HILL DIST: " + distanceToAnt(antHillX, antHillY));
    if (getNearestAnt(ants) != null &&  distanceToAnt(getNearestAnt(ants).getX(), getNearestAnt(ants).getY()) < 100) {
      // Move towards the nearest ant
      Ant nearestAnt = getNearestAnt(ants);
      int nearestAntX = nearestAnt.getX();
      int nearestAntY = nearestAnt.getY();
      moveTowards(nearestAntX, nearestAntY, ants);
    }
    else if (distanceToAnt(antHillX, antHillY) < 150){
      moveTowards(antHillX, antHillY, ants);
      rX = antHillX;
      rY = antHillY;
      if(distanceToAnt(antHillX, antHillY) <= 10){
        antHill.takeDamge();
      }
    }
    else{
      //RANDOM MOVEMENT
      if(distanceToAnt(rX,rY) < 10){
        atTarget = true;
        //System.out.println("at target");
      }
      if(atTarget){
        int nrX = (int) Math.floor(Math.random() *(WIDTH - 0 + 1) + 0);
        rY = (int) Math.floor(Math.random() *(HEIGHT - 0 + 1) + 0);
        if(player.equals("p1") && rX != 0){
          while(nrX < rX){
            nrX = (int) Math.floor(Math.random() *(WIDTH - 0 + 1) + 0);
          }
        }
        else if(rX != 0){
          while(nrX > rX){
            nrX = (int) Math.floor(Math.random() *(WIDTH - 0 + 1) + 0);
          }
        }
        rX = nrX;
        atTarget = false;
        //System.out.println("target is X:" + rX + " Y:" + rY);
      }
      
      moveTowards(rX, rY, ants);
    } 
    
  }

  private int distanceToAnt(int x, int y) {
    int dx = x - this.x;
    int dy = y - this.y;
    return (int) Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
  }

  private Ant getNearestAnt(ArrayList<Ant> ants) {
    Ant nearestAnt = null;
    double minDistance = Double.MAX_VALUE;

    for (Ant ant : ants) {
      int distance = distanceToAnt(ant.getX(), ant.getY());
      if (distance < minDistance) {
        minDistance = distance;
        nearestAnt = ant;
      }
    }

    return nearestAnt;
  }

  private void moveTowards(int targetX, int targetY, ArrayList<Ant> ants) {
    int dx = targetX - x;
    int dy = targetY - y;
    int distance = (int) Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);

    if (distance > 0) {
      int nspeed = (int) speed/3;
      int moveX = (int) Math.round((double) dx / distance * nspeed);
      int moveY = (int) Math.round((double) dy / distance * nspeed);

      if (!isCollidingWithOtherAnt(ants)) {
        x += moveX;
        y += moveY;
      }
      else{
        //collision
        attackAnt(getNearestAnt(ants));
      }
    }
  }

  private boolean isCollidingWithOtherAnt(ArrayList<Ant> ants) {
    for (Ant ant : ants) {
      if (ant != this && isColliding(ant)) {
        return true;
      }
    }
    return false;
  }

  private boolean isColliding(Ant otherAnt) {
    int radius = 10; // Adjust the radius as needed for collision detection
    int dx = x - otherAnt.getX();
    int dy = y - otherAnt.getY();
    int distanceSquared = dx * dx + dy * dy;
    int minDistanceSquared = radius * radius * 4; // Adjust the factor (4) as needed for collision detection

    return distanceSquared < minDistanceSquared;
  }

  public BufferedImage getImg() {
    BufferedImage img = spriteSheet;
    BufferedImage new_img = spriteSheet;

    if (ani_step == 0)
      new_img = img.getSubimage(0, 0, 96, 101);
    else if (ani_step == 1)
      new_img = img.getSubimage(96, 0, 96, 101);
    else if (ani_step == 2)
      new_img = img.getSubimage(192, 0, 96, 101);
    else
      new_img = img.getSubimage(288, 0, 96, 101);

    if (ani_dir)
      ani_step++;
    else
      ani_step--;
    if (ani_step >= 4) {
      ani_dir = false;
    }
    if (ani_step <= 0) {
      ani_dir = true;
    }

    return new_img;
  }

  public void attackAnt(Ant ant) {
    ant.takeDamage(damage);
  }

  public void takeDamage(double amt) {
    health -= amt;
  }

  public double getHealth() {
    return health;
  }

  public double getSpeed() {
    return speed;
  }

  public double getDamage() {
    return damage;
  }

  public String getName() {
    return name;
  }

  public int getX() {
    return x;
  }

  public int getY() {
    return y;
  }

  public void draw(Graphics g) {
    g.drawImage(getImg(), x, y, getImg().getWidth() / size_cut, getImg().getHeight() / size_cut, null);
    g.drawLine(rX,rY,x,y+10);
  }

}

There are some other dependencies such as BulletAnt.java, FireAnt.java, and AntMound.java but I didn't think they were relevant to the issue, but let me know if would help to see them.

Any and all help would be greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance!

answers.title: Ant copy task ignoring files
answers.body:
From the PatternSet section in the Ant manual: http://ant.apache.org/manual/Types/patternset.html

Note that while the includes and excludes attributes accept multiple elements separated by commas or spaces, the nested <include> and <exclude> elements expect their name attribute to hold a single pattern.

You could change your script to something like

<copy todir="./Virgo/config" overwrite="true" verbose="true">
    <fileset dir="${config.folder}">
        <include name="*.properties" />
        <include name="*.xml" />
    </fileset>
</copy>

answers.body_markdown:
To those that are confused as to why `copy` is not working, it could be because the [Copy task][1] will only copy files if the source is newer than the destination.

Specify `overwrite="true"` to ensure that the copy happens.


  [1]: https://ant.apache.org/manual/Tasks/copy.html

answers.body_markdown:
What you're trying to do here won't work because the properties are loaded before the bean is created.  Plus, that's not the correct syntax for SpEL to invoke methods on beans.  If you want to externalize these to a file, try something like this:

1. Ditch the dotenv thing, you won't need this.
2. Create a file called .env.properties that contains the values you want
3. Add this configuration to your application properties

    spring.config.import=optional:file:.env.properties
4. Any property defined in .env.properties is available for injection via `@Value`

The location of the `.env.properties` file is important, it needs to be in the current working directory of the running java process.  You can also use absolute paths here, like     `spring.config.import=optional:file:/opt/secure/.env.properties`, or, better yet, you can replace the path with a variable reference and set an environment variable like this. `spring.config.import=optional:file:${ENV_FILE}`, `export ENV_FILE=/opt/secure/.env.properties`.

I prefer to use Vault for stuff like this.
answers.title: Set up Spring Boot application.properties file with database url/username/password in an .env file
answers.body:
What you're trying to do here won't work because the properties are loaded before the bean is created. Plus, that's not the correct syntax for SpEL to invoke methods on beans. If you want to externalize these to a file, try something like this:

  1. Ditch the dotenv thing, you won't need this.

  2. Create a file called .env.properties that contains the values you want

  3. Add this configuration to your application properties

    spring.config.import=optional:file:.env.properties

  4. Any property defined in .env.properties is available for injection via @Value

The location of the .env.properties file is important, it needs to be in the current working directory of the running java process. You can also use absolute paths here, like spring.config.import=optional:file:/opt/secure/.env.properties, or, better yet, you can replace the path with a variable reference and set an environment variable like this. spring.config.import=optional:file:${ENV_FILE}, export ENV_FILE=/opt/secure/.env.properties.

I prefer to use Vault for stuff like this.

answers.title: How to validate if after clicking on a link it gets disabled until redirecting to next page?
answers.body:
You can follow these steps:

  • Locate the link element using Selenium WebDriver. You can use various methods such as findElement(By) or findElements(By) to find the link element based on its attributes (e.g., ID, class, or XPath).
  • Click on the link using the click() method of the WebElement representing the link.
  • Wait for the link to become disabled. You can use explicit or implicit waits to wait for a certain condition to be met. In this case, you can wait until the link becomes disabled by checking its "disabled" attribute or any other indicator of its disabled state.

// Find and click on the link
WebElement link = driver.findElement(By.linkText("Your Link Text"));
link.click();

// Wait for the link to become disabled
WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, 10);
wait.until(ExpectedConditions.attributeToBe(link, "disabled", "true"));

// Perform validation or assertions here
boolean isLinkDisabled = link.getAttribute("disabled").equals("true");
System.out.println("Is link disabled? " + isLinkDisabled);

answers.title: How to validate if after clicking on a link it gets disabled until redirecting to next page?
answers.body:
HTML disabled Attribute

The boolean disabled attribute, when present, makes the element non mutable, non focusable and even can't be submitted with the form. The user can't edit or focus on the control nor its form control descendants as well.

As an example:

<form>
    <label for="empDate">Employment Date:</label>
    <input name="empDate" type="date" disabled>
</form>

This usecase

So to validate if clicking on a link the link gets disabled until redirecting to next page you can use the following strategy:

// find and click on the link
driver.findElement(By.xpath("//input[@name='link']")).click();
// validate if the link is disabled
try
{
    driver.findElement(By.xpath("//input[@name='link' and @disabled]"));
    System.out.println("Link was disabled");
}
catch(NoSuchElementException ex)
{
    System.out.println("Link wasn't disabled");
}

answers.body_markdown:
Replace 
`pst.executeUpdate(query2);`
with 
`pst.executeUpdate();`

Otherwise you will end up ignoring the parameter binding you did with with the various `pst.setString(...)` hence the db engine will receive a query with `?` instead of the values you meant to bind.

items.title: incrementing Pool size with initial connections and max connections
items.body:
I'm doing a Pool app where there are 3 variables, A as initial connections which is 20, b as incrementing size meaning that when the pool reach 20, it will increment 5 by 5 the pool size, and y as the max connections that is 50, I'm having problems implementing the B variable in a conditional way, this is the code

public class ThreadHolder extends Thread {
    ArrayList<Client> pool;
    public static int a = 20;
    public static int b = 5;
    public static int y = 50;
    public static long ftime, stime, time;
    public Client c = null;
    
    public ThreadHolder(){
        pool = new ArrayList<Client>();
    }
    
    public void run(){
        stime = System.currentTimeMillis();
        try {
            while(pool.size()<= y){     
                if(pool.size() < a){    
                    poolHelper();
                    Thread.sleep(600);
                }
                
                else if(pool.size()> a){
                    a = a+b;
                    poolHelper();
                    Thread.sleep(600);
                }   
                
                else {
                    System.out.println("----------------------------------");
                    System.out.println("Database is busy, please try again in a second.");  
                    deleteClient(c);
                    System.out.println("Pool -> "+pool.size() + ".");
                    Thread.sleep(300);
            }   
                
            ftime = System.currentTimeMillis();
            time = (ftime - stime)/1000 ;
            System.out.println("Time established -> " + time + " sec");
            }   
        }catch(Exception e) {e.printStackTrace();}
    }
    
    public void poolHelper(){
        obtainClient(c);
        addClient(c);
        System.out.println("Pool -> "+pool.size() + ".");
    }
    
    public synchronized void obtainClient(Client c){
        Client a = new Client(this);
        a.start();
    }
    
    public synchronized void addClient(Client c){
        pool.add(c);
    }
    
    public synchronized void deleteClient(Client c){
        pool.remove(c);
    }
}

How can I implement the use of B, to keep adding clients to my pool when my poolsize reach more than 20 connections?

comments.body_markdown: You break out of the loop if you find an element, so it stops looping *(hence it stops searching)*. Tangentially: if the list being searched is large *(for various values of "large")* instead of searching again it might make more sense to iterate backwards/forwards until a non-match, but for small-ish lists it's likely not a necessary optimization.
comments.body: You break out of the loop if you find an element, so it stops looping (hence it stops searching). Tangentially: if the list being searched is large (for various values of "large") instead of searching again it might make more sense to iterate backwards/forwards until a non-match, but for small-ish lists it's likely not a necessary optimization.

answers.body_markdown:
Google can transfer you to practicing tutorial websites (much better than I can).  A nice real time scenario could include any of the following (may seem academic, but the skills are absolutely transferable to practice):

  1.  Dining philosopher's problem.
  2.  Reader/Writer problem.
  3.  Consumer/Producer problem.

Some more specific ones:

  1.  Concurrent alpha-beta search (this is seriously tricky).
  2.  Any genetic algorithm can be implemented concurrently and since memory/storage are shared amongst threads, it can be quite challenging if done right (try the semi-transparent polygon drawing an image project. You can search google for that).
  3.  Concurrent database-access can be rather interesting.  Sketch a scenario for yourself.
  4.  Have a look at http://projecteuler.net/ which includes a bunch of interesting problems.  Many of the problems there can be implemented using threads.

Enjoy.

Some more specific ones:

  1. Concurrent alpha-beta search (this is seriously tricky).
  2. Any genetic algorithm can be implemented concurrently and since memory/storage are shared amongst threads, it can be quite challenging if done right (try the semi-transparent polygon drawing an image project. You can search google for that).
  3. Concurrent database-access can be rather interesting. Sketch a scenario for yourself.
  4. Have a look at http://projecteuler.net/ which includes a bunch of interesting problems. Many of the problems there can be implemented using threads.

Enjoy.

answers.body_markdown:
There are several problems with Java that are just crying out for a multi-threaded solution. Two I've hit recently and solved were:

 - **File.list** has horrible problems if there are many thousands of files in the folder.
 - **SAXParser.parse** is a push parser. Many xml users would prefer a pull parser but would rather not add yet another library.

Both of these can be helped considerably using a simple two-thread solution.

In the case of **File.list**, run the `File.list` in a separate thread with a special `FileFilter` that posts all files presented to it to a `BlockingQueue`. An iterator on the `BlockingQueue` can then be used to deliver the files to the caller. An enhancement to list the directory recursively is an easy addition if the code is written correctly.

The **SAXParser.parse** can be turned inside-out in a similar way.

I have done both of these quite recently and found the experience very enlightening.
answers.title: Java Multi Threading - real world use cases
answers.body:
There are several problems with Java that are just crying out for a multi-threaded solution. Two I've hit recently and solved were:

  • File.list has horrible problems if there are many thousands of files in the folder.
  • SAXParser.parse is a push parser. Many xml users would prefer a pull parser but would rather not add yet another library.

Both of these can be helped considerably using a simple two-thread solution.

In the case of File.list, run the File.list in a separate thread with a special FileFilter that posts all files presented to it to a BlockingQueue. An iterator on the BlockingQueue can then be used to deliver the files to the caller. An enhancement to list the directory recursively is an easy addition if the code is written correctly.

The SAXParser.parse can be turned inside-out in a similar way.

I have done both of these quite recently and found the experience very enlightening.

answers.body_markdown:
Multi-threading simulated by user-level threads. These threads are implemented at application level not OS Kernel level.  

These threads also called Green threads because, so fresh(brand new) and young(not ripe or mature).

**Real world use cases**

- In **Computer Games**, objects like cars, motor bikes etc. They are just threads.  
- **Asynchronous communication** can allow an application to perform additional tasks instead of waiting for tasks to complete. 
- Applications that have a number of tasks that can be performed in any order can often benefit from distributed asynchronous communication.

answers.body_markdown:
When single thread is taking long time to complete a computational activity, you should break it into small tasks and use multi-threading to reduce computation time. 

You can see lot of use cases for multi threading in your project. 

1. Where some tasks can run independently  with-out depending on other tasks ( Just span a new `Thread` or submit `Runnable/Callable` tasks to `ExecutorService/ThreadPoolExecutor`)
2. When you need to wait for completion of multiple parallel tasks to proceed with next task ( `invokeAll()`)

   e.g. Task 1 starts three independent tasks Task 2, Task 3 and Task 4 but Task 5 has to start after completion of Task 2, Task 3 and Task 4. 

>      Task 1              
>     ----->               
>              Task 2
>              ----->
>              Task 3
>              ----->
>              Task 4
>              ----->
>                       Task 5
>     -------------------------->
>                       
                    

3. System is capable of using multiple **CPU cores**
4. When you have use cases like **Fork-Join** tasks ( use: [ForkJoinPool][1])
5. When you want to show progress of long computation task ( Progress bar can be shown in one thread and long computation task can be executed by other Thread) 

Related posts:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33596079/how-to-properly-use-java-executor/33596230#33596230

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34440604/whether-to-use-invokeall-or-submit-java-executor-service/34798567#34798567

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21156599/javas-fork-join-vs-executorservice-when-to-use-which/34922218#34922218

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7939257/wait-until-all-threads-finish-their-work-in-java/36797569#36797569


  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/ForkJoinPool.html

comments.body_markdown: For a large PriorityQueue, where you know most elements up front, this is indeed the way to go. However, often one uses a PriorityQueue when the elements are not known up front, so that optimization is rarely possible. And if one knows *all* elements up front, a simple `Arrays.sort` is often than creating and draining a `PriorityQueue`. So the case you are describing is rather rare, which possibly explain the oversight in the API.

comments.body_markdown: The thing is that draining a `PriorityQueue`, i.e. retrieving all elements, is O(n log n), and if you do that, `Arrays.sort` has a slightly better constant factor. If you don't drain the entire `PriorityQueue`, as in your top K example, the `PriorityQueue` is much better than Arrays.sort. Another option would be to only keep the top K elements in the `PriorityQueue`, resulting in an O(n log k) algorithm, which, due to slightly better constant factors, might be a bit faster. But your approach is fine.

answers.title: Building priority queue in linear time
answers.body:
Your test is likely flawed, because the following test shows a clear difference:

class Counter {
    int comparisons = 0;
    
    class Item implements Comparable<Item> {
        final int value;
        
        Item(int value) {
            this.value = value;
        }

        @Override
        public int compareTo(Item o) {
            comparisons++;
            return value - o.value;
        }
        
        @Override
        public String toString() {
            return Integer.toString(value);
        }
    }
}

public class Test {
    static void count(int n) {
        var c = new Counter();
        var items = new ArrayList<Counter.Item>();
        for (int i = n - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
            items.add(c.new Item(i));
        }
        new PriorityQueue<>(items);
        
        var c2 = new Counter();
        var pq2 = new PriorityQueue<>();
        for (int i = n - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
            pq2.add(c2.new Item(i));
        }
        System.out.println(n + "\t" + c.comparisons + "\t" + c2.comparisons);
    }
    
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        for (int i = 1; i < (1 << 20); i = (i << 1) | 1) {
            count(i);
        }
    }
}

by printing

1   0   0
3   2   2
7   8   10
15  22  34
31  52  98
63  114 258
127 240 642
255 494 1538
511 1004    3586
1023    2026    8194
2047    4072    18434
4095    8166    40962
8191    16356   90114
16383   32738   196610
32767   65504   425986
65535   131038  917506
131071  262108  1966082
262143  524250  4194306
524287  1048536 8912898
1048575 2097110 18874370

That is, while both approaches use a roughly equal number of comparisons for small lists, they scale differently. To compare this with linear scaling, we can change our code to:

    System.out.println(
            n 
            + "\t" + ((double) c.comparisons / n) 
            + "\t" + ((double) c2.comparisons / n)
    );

and get

1   0.0 0.0
3   0.6666666666666666  0.6666666666666666
7   1.1428571428571428  1.4285714285714286
15  1.4666666666666666  2.2666666666666666
31  1.6774193548387097  3.161290322580645
63  1.8095238095238095  4.095238095238095
127 1.889763779527559   5.05511811023622
255 1.9372549019607843  6.031372549019608
511 1.9647749510763208  7.01761252446184
1023    1.9804496578690127  8.009775171065494
2047    1.9892525647288715  9.005373717635564
4095    1.9941391941391942  10.002930402930403
8191    1.9968257843975095  11.001587107801246
16383   1.9982909113105047  12.000854544344747
32767   1.99908444471572    13.00045777764214
65535   1.9995117112993057  14.000244144350347
131071  1.999740598606862   15.000129700696569
262143  1.9998626703745666  16.000068664812716
524287  1.9999275206137097  17.000036239693145
1048575 1.999961852990964   18.000019073504518

confirming that the constructor needs about 2n comparisons, while repeatedly calling add() needs
n ((log2 n) - 2) comparisons.

So, why is heapify faster? Its implementation reads:

    private void heapify() {
        final Object[] es = queue;
        int n = size, i = (n >>> 1) - 1;
        final Comparator<? super E> cmp;
        if ((cmp = comparator) == null)
            for (; i >= 0; i--)
                siftDownComparable(i, (E) es[i], es, n);
        else
            for (; i >= 0; i--)
                siftDownUsingComparator(i, (E) es[i], es, n, cmp);
    }

and

    private static <T> void siftDownComparable(int k, T x, Object[] es, int n) {
        // assert n > 0;
        Comparable<? super T> key = (Comparable<? super T>)x;
        int half = n >>> 1;           // loop while a non-leaf
        while (k < half) {
            int child = (k << 1) + 1; // assume left child is least
            Object c = es[child];
            int right = child + 1;
            if (right < n &&
                ((Comparable<? super T>) c).compareTo((T) es[right]) > 0)
                c = es[child = right];
            if (key.compareTo((T) c) <= 0)
                break;
            es[k] = c;
            k = child;
        }
        es[k] = key;
    }

At first glance, it seems surprising that heapify should have linear complexity, because it calls siftDown n/2 times, and siftDown requires up to 2 log2(n) comparisons. But let's take a closer look:

In the worst case, heapify involves moving down each node until it is a leaf node. The cost therefore is the total distance of nodes from the leaves of the tree, or

n * h

where h is the average distance from a leaf. What is that distance?

Since a heap is a fully balanced tree, adding a new level of nodes to the tree adds 1 to the distance of existing nodes, and then adds equally many nodes at distance 0, which halves the average distance:

h <- (h + 1) / 2

To find what this recurrence relation converges to, we set

h = (h + 1) / 2

and obtain

2h = h + 1
 h = 1

That is, the average distance from a leaf in an infinite fully balanced search tree is 1. And that's why siftDown, on average, needs constant time, and heapify is linear.

In contrast, if we add() a node, the following executes:

public boolean offer(E e) {
    if (e == null)
        throw new NullPointerException();
    modCount++;
    int i = size;
    if (i >= queue.length)
        grow(i + 1);
    siftUp(i, e);
    size = i + 1;
    return true;
}

where

private void siftUp(int k, E x) {
    if (comparator != null)
        siftUpUsingComparator(k, x, queue, comparator);
    else
        siftUpComparable(k, x, queue);
}

private static <T> void siftUpComparable(int k, T x, Object[] es) {
    Comparable<? super T> key = (Comparable<? super T>) x;
    while (k > 0) {
        int parent = (k - 1) >>> 1;
        Object e = es[parent];
        if (key.compareTo((T) e) >= 0)
            break;
        es[k] = e;
        k = parent;
    }
    es[k] = key;
}

In the worst case, add moves every node all the way to the root. The overall cost therefore is total distance from the root, i.e.

n * d

where d is the average distance from the root.

To find the average distance from the root, imaging drawing, from each node, a path to the root. Then, the root node is visited for every node that is not the root, each of the 2 nodes beneath are visited (n-3)/2 times, each of the 4 below (n-7)/4 times, and so on:

nd = n * 1/1 + (n-1) * 2/2 + (n-3) * 4/4 + (n-7) * 8/8 + ...
   = n + (n-1) + (n-3) + (n-7) + ... + (n - (n/2 - 1))
   = n * log2(n/2) - (1 + 3 + 7 + ... + (n/2 - 1))
   > n * log2(n/2) - (2 + 4 + 8 + ... + (n/2))
   = n * log2(n/2) - n
   = n * (log2(n) - 2)

which matches what we measured.

That is, heapify is faster because the average node in a fully balanced binary tree is very close to a leaf, but far from the root.

items.title: Building priority queue in linear time
items.body:
There are two ways to build a priority queue:

// 1.
PriorityQueue<Integer> pq = new PriorityQueue<>();  
pq.addAll(collection);  

// 2.
PriorityQueue<Integer> pq = new PriorityQueue<>(collection);
  • Approach #1 uses the addAll method to add each element one by one to the priority queue, so there will be n iterations (size of the collection) of the for-loop; and for each iteration there will be a siftUp operation which could take O(log n) time in the worst case. So approach #1 will take O(n log n) time.
  • Approach #2 uses the heapify() method which takes O(n) to build the heap.

So it seems approach #2 would be better.

I am not sure about the above analysis. Also, I tested this on a custom object with a custom comparator function, but didn't see any performance improvement. Maybe the amount of data was too small to see any improvement.
Any thoughts on these?

items.title: Functions of adding `this` to methods & static and instance methods [Java]
items.body:
For one of my programming assignments, I was tasked to write a couple methods. I noticed that one of my methods could be expressed as using an if-else statement between two methods I already defined. I cannot change the method signatures to make those two other methods static.

I heard somewhere/was briefly taught that you can add this in front of the method (this.method()). Does that change it so that instance methods could be use statically? What does adding this specifically do? Is it "good practice" to use it like this?

Pseudocode for two methods:

public boolean methodA(input){
    //does something
    return true or false depending on something;
}
public boolean methodB(input){
    //does something else
    return true or false depending on something else;
}

I noticed after coding that I can call the methods inside each other without using this so my question really is, which is better/more reliable? Using this vs. not using this???

public boolean methodAB(input){
    boolean present = input is already present;
    if(present) {return methodA();}
    else {return methodB();}
}

or...

public boolean methodAB(input){
    boolean present = input is already present;
    if(present) {return this.methodA();}
    else {return this.methodB();}
}
